廖剑伟

General Information

Full Name Jianwei Liao
Date of Birth 1981
Languages Chinese, English, Japanese

Experience

  • 2018 - PRESENT
    Professor of Southwest University | Doctoral Supervisor
    College of Computer and Information Science, Southwest University of China
  • 2013 - 2018
    Associate professor of Southwest University
    College of Computer and Information Science, Southwest University of China
  • 2015 - 2017
    Postdoc researcher
    the AICS of RIKEN, Japan
    • Working on the FUGAKA supercomputer project
  • 2008 - 2012
    Ph.D.
    Computer science from the University of Tokyo, Japan

Foundation

  • 2019 - 2022
    主持 国家自然科学基金（面上）：面向高性能计算平台的多级层次结构的并行存储系统的优化技术研究
    • 本项目研究了具有多级层次体系结构的并行存储系统的I/O优化支撑技术，为高性能计算机集群提供具有高性能、可扩展和低延迟等特性的存储基础设施。具体而言，考虑到高性能计算机集群往往采用多级层次体系结构的事实，通过研究与I/O结点与存储结点（含存储设备）相匹配层次的I/O优化策略（包括分布式缓存管理优化机制和数据复本放置策略），构建易于维护和扩展的高性能存储子系统。
  • 2021 - 2024
    主持 重庆市自然科学基金（重点）：基于 RAID 的固态硬盘 I/O 优化机制研究
  • 2021 - 2025
    参与（排名：7/12）-国家自然科学基金（重点项目）：人机物三元融合场景的泛在计算抽象和软件定义方法
    • 该项目研究建立人机物融合场景的计算模型和计算理论，并在此基础上，设计、开发、部署和运维诸如灾后联合救援和跨域健康紧急救护的人机物融合场景应用。该项目中云计算平台建设需要考虑人机物场景应用的数据访问特征，研究实现高性能的存储基础设施。
  • 2015 - 2017
    主持 国家自然科学基金委员会-广东联合基金（超级计算科学应用研究专项）
    • 该项目主要研究支持RAID机制的高可靠固态硬盘I/O优化机制，包括负载均衡、条带重组和DRAM缓存管理等相关研究。
  • 2018 - 2020
    主持 重庆市自然科学基金（面上）：面向大数据存储的并行文件系统优化机制研究

Honors and Awards

Academic Interests

  • Dependable operating systems
  • High-performance storage systems
    • SSD
    • HDD

Pulications

  1. Degraded Mode-Benefited I/O Scheduling to Ensure I/O Responsiveness in RAID-Enabled SSDs
    Zhibing Sha, Jun Li, Zhigang Cai, and 3 more authors
    ACM Trans. Des. Autom. Electron. Syst., Nov 2022
    Abs

    RAID-enabled SSDs commonly have unbalanced I/O workloads on their components (e.g., SSD channels), as the data/parity chunks in the same stripe may have varied access frequency, which greatly impacts I/O responsiveness. This article proposes a I/O scheduling scheme by resorting to the degraded read mode and the read-modify-write mode to reduce the long-tail latency of I/O requests in RAID-enabled SSDs. The basic idea is to avoid scheduling read or update requests to the heavily congested but targeted RAID components. Such requests are satisfied by accessing other relevant RAID components by certain XOR computations (we call the degraded modes). Specially, we build a queuing overhead assessment model on the top of factors of data redundancy and the current blocked I/O traffics on SSD channels to precisely dispatch incoming I/O requests to be fulfilled with the degraded mode or not. The trace-driven experiments illustrate that the proposed scheme can reduce the long-tail latency of read requests by 23.1% on average at the 99.99th percentile, in contrast to state-of-the-art scheduling methods.
